The **Philadelphia Eagles** are a professional [American
football](/wiki/American_football "American football") franchise based in
[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia"). The Eagles
compete in the [National Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League
"National Football League") (NFL) as a member club of the league's [National
Football Conference](/wiki/National_Football_Conference "National Football
Conference") (NFC) [East](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC East") division. They are [Super
Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") champions, having won [Super Bowl
LII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII "Super Bowl LII"), their fourth NFL title, after
winning in [1948](/wiki/1948_NFL_Championship_Game "1948 NFL Championship
Game"), [1949](/wiki/1949_NFL_Championship_Game "1949 NFL Championship Game"),
and [1960](/wiki/1960_NFL_Championship_Game "1960 NFL Championship Game").

The franchise was established in 1933 as a replacement for the bankrupt
[Frankford Yellow Jackets](/wiki/Frankford_Yellow_Jackets "Frankford Yellow
Jackets"), when a group led by [Bert Bell](/wiki/Bert_Bell "Bert Bell")
secured the rights to an NFL franchise in Philadelphia. Bell, [Chuck
Bednarik](/wiki/Chuck_Bednarik "Chuck Bednarik"), [Bob
Brown](/wiki/Bob_Brown_\(offensive_lineman\) "Bob Brown \(offensive
lineman\)"), [Brian Dawkins](/wiki/Brian_Dawkins "Brian Dawkins"), [Reggie
White](/wiki/Reggie_White "Reggie White"), [Steve Van
Buren](/wiki/Steve_Van_Buren "Steve Van Buren"), [Tommy
McDonald](/wiki/Tommy_McDonald_\(American_football\) "Tommy McDonald
\(American football\)"), [Greasy Neale](/wiki/Greasy_Neale "Greasy Neale"),
[Pete Pihos](/wiki/Pete_Pihos "Pete Pihos"), [Sonny
Jurgensen](/wiki/Sonny_Jurgensen "Sonny Jurgensen"), and [Norm Van
Brocklin](/wiki/Norm_Van_Brocklin "Norm Van Brocklin") have been inducted to
the [Pro Football Hall of Fame](/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football
Hall of Fame").

The team has an [intense rivalry](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Giants_rivalry
"Eagles–Giants rivalry") with the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New
York Giants"). This rivalry is the oldest in the [NFC East](/wiki/NFC_East
"NFC East") and is among the oldest in the NFL. It was ranked by [NFL
Network](/wiki/NFL_Network "NFL Network") as the number one rivalry of all-
time and _[Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")_
ranks it amongst the Top 10 NFL rivalries of all-time at number four,[4] and
according to [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN"), it is one of the fiercest and most
well-known rivalries in the American football community.[5] They also have a
[bitter rivalry](/wiki/Cowboys%E2%80%93Eagles_rivalry "Cowboys–Eagles
rivalry") with the [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"),
which has become more high-profile since the 1960s, as well as a [historic
rivalry](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Redskins_rivalry "Eagles–Redskins rivalry") with
the [Washington Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins").
Their rivalry with the [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers
"Pittsburgh Steelers") is another [bitter
rivalry](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry "Eagles–Steelers rivalry"),
roughly dating back to 1933, that mostly arises from the two teams' statuses
as being from opposite ends of the [same state](/wiki/Pennsylvania
"Pennsylvania").[6]

The team consistently ranks in the top three in attendance and has sold out
every game since the 1999 season.[7][8] In a _Sports Illustrated_ poll of 321
NFL players, Eagles fans were selected the most intimidating fans in the
NFL.[9]

## Franchise history

Main article: [History of the Philadelphia
Eagles](/wiki/History_of_the_Philadelphia_Eagles "History of the Philadelphia
Eagles")

### 1931–1960

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/ChuckBednarik1952Bowman.jpg/220px-
ChuckBednarik1952Bowman.jpg)](/wiki/File:ChuckBednarik1952Bowman.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ChuckBednarik1952Bowman.jpg "Enlarge")

["Concrete Charlie"](/wiki/Chuck_Bednarik "Chuck Bednarik")

Midway through the [1931 season](/wiki/1931_NFL_season "1931 NFL season"), the
[Frankford Yellow Jackets](/wiki/Frankford_Yellow_Jackets "Frankford Yellow
Jackets") went bankrupt and ceased operations.[10] After more than a year of
searching for a suitable replacement, the NFL granted an expansion franchise
to a syndicate headed by [Bert Bell](/wiki/Bert_Bell "Bert Bell") and [Lud
Wray](/wiki/Lud_Wray "Lud Wray") and awarded them the franchise rights of the
failed Yellow Jackets organization. The Bell-Wray group had to pay an entry
fee of $3,500 (equal to $40,230 today) and assumed a total debt of $11,000
that was owed to three other NFL franchises.[11] Drawing inspiration from the
[Blue Eagle](/wiki/Blue_Eagle "Blue Eagle") insignia of the [National Recovery
Administration](/wiki/National_Recovery_Administration "National Recovery
Administration")—the centerpiece of President [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt")'s [New
Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal")[11]—Bell and Wray named the new franchise the
Philadelphia Eagles. Neither the Eagles nor the NFL officially regard the two
franchises as the same, citing the aforementioned period of dormancy.
Furthermore, almost no Yellow Jackets players were on the Eagles' first
roster. The Eagles, along with the [Pittsburgh
Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") and the now-defunct
[Cincinnati Reds](/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds_\(NFL\) "Cincinnati Reds \(NFL\)"),
joined the NFL as [expansion teams](/wiki/Expansion_team "Expansion team").

In 1937, the Eagles moved to [Shibe Park](/wiki/Shibe_Park "Shibe Park")
(renamed [Connie Mack Stadium](/wiki/Connie_Mack_Stadium "Connie Mack
Stadium") in 1954) and played their home games at the stadium through 1957,
except for the 1941 season, which was played at [Municipal
Stadium](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Stadium_\(Philadelphia\) "John F. Kennedy
Stadium \(Philadelphia\)"), where they had played from 1936 to 1939.

> To accommodate football at Shibe Park during the winter, management set up
> stands in right field, parallel to 20th Street. Some 20 feet high, these
> "east stands" had 22 rows of seats. The goalposts stood along the first base
> line and in left field. The uncovered east stands enlarged capacity of Shibe
> Park to over 39,000, but the Eagles rarely drew more than 25 to 30,000.[12]

The Eagles struggled over the course of their first decade, enduring repeated
losing seasons. In December 1940, [Pittsburgh
Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") owner [Art
Rooney](/wiki/Art_Rooney "Art Rooney") sold his franchise to [Alexis
Thompson](/wiki/Alexis_Thompson "Alexis Thompson") for $160,000 and then used
half of the proceeds to buy a half interest in the Eagles from Bell, his
longtime friend.[13] Soon after, Bell and Rooney traded the Eagles franchise
to Thompson and moved it to Pittsburgh (as the "Steelers"), while Thompson
moved the Steelers franchise to Philadelphia (as the "Eagles").[13]

In 1943, when manpower shortages stemming from World War II made it impossible
to fill the roster, the team merged with the Pittsburgh Steelers forming the
"Phil-Pitt Eagles" and were known as the "[Steagles](/wiki/Steagles
"Steagles")." (The merger, never intended as a permanent arrangement, was
dissolved at the end of the [1943 season](/wiki/1943_NFL_season "1943 NFL
season").) By the late 1940s, head coach [Earle "Greasy"
Neale](/wiki/Greasy_Neale "Greasy Neale") and running back [Steve Van
Buren](/wiki/Steve_Van_Buren "Steve Van Buren") led the team to three
consecutive NFL Championship Games, winning two of them in
[1948](/wiki/1948_NFL_season "1948 NFL season") and
[1949](/wiki/1949_NFL_season "1949 NFL season"). Those two championships mark
the Eagles as the only NFL team ever to win back-to-back championships by
shutouts, defeating the [Chicago
Cardinals](/wiki/1948_Chicago_Cardinals_season "1948 Chicago Cardinals
season"), 7–0, in [1948](/wiki/1948_NFL_Championship_Game "1948 NFL
Championship Game")—in a blizzard—and the [Los Angeles
Rams](/wiki/1949_Los_Angeles_Rams_season "1949 Los Angeles Rams season"),
14–0, in [1949](/wiki/1949_NFL_Championship_Game "1949 NFL Championship
Game").

After the [1957 season](/wiki/1957_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "1957
Philadelphia Eagles season"), the Eagles moved from Connie Mack Stadium to
[Franklin Field](/wiki/Franklin_Field "Franklin Field") at the University of
Pennsylvania. Franklin Field would seat over 60,000 for the Eagles, whereas
Connie Mack had a capacity of 39,000.[14] The stadium switched from grass to
[AstroTurf](/wiki/AstroTurf "AstroTurf") in 1969. It was the first NFL stadium
to use artificial turf.

In [1960](/wiki/1960_NFL_season "1960 NFL season"), the Eagles won their
[third NFL championship](/wiki/1960_NFL_Championship_Game "1960 NFL
Championship Game"), under the leadership of future [Pro Football Hall of
Famers](/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame") [Norm Van
Brocklin](/wiki/Norm_Van_Brocklin "Norm Van Brocklin") and [Chuck
Bednarik](/wiki/Chuck_Bednarik "Chuck Bednarik"); the head coach was [Buck
Shaw](/wiki/Buck_Shaw "Buck Shaw"). The [1960
Eagles](/wiki/1960_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "1960 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), by a score of 17–13, became the only team to defeat [Vince
Lombardi](/wiki/Vince_Lombardi "Vince Lombardi") and his [Green Bay
Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers") in the playoffs.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Dickvermeil.jpg/200px-
Dickvermeil.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dickvermeil.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dickvermeil.jpg "Enlarge")

[Dick Vermeil](/wiki/Dick_Vermeil "Dick Vermeil"), Eagles head coach from 1976
to 1982

### 1961–1975

The Eagles had a decent [1961 season](/wiki/1961_Philadelphia_Eagles_season
"1961 Philadelphia Eagles season") and then fell on hard times in 1962. [Jerry
Wolman](/wiki/Jerry_Wolman "Jerry Wolman"), after consulting his longtime
friend Brandon Sturrock, bought the franchise in 1963 from the "[Happy
Hundred](/wiki/Happy_Hundred "Happy Hundred")", a group of investors who owned
the team from 1949–1963, for $5,505,000 (equal to $44,004,098 today).[14]

In [1969](/wiki/1969_NFL_season "1969 NFL season"), [Leonard
Tose](/wiki/Leonard_Tose "Leonard Tose") bought the Eagles from Wolman for
$16,155,000[15] (equal to $107,807,505 today), then a record for a
professional sports franchise. Tose's first official act was to fire Coach
[Joe Kuharich](/wiki/Joe_Kuharich "Joe Kuharich") after a disappointing
24–41–1 record during his five-year reign. He followed this by naming former
Eagles receiving great [Pete Retzlaff](/wiki/Pete_Retzlaff "Pete Retzlaff") as
[General Manager](/wiki/General_manager "General manager") and [Jerry
Williams](/wiki/Jerry_Williams_\(American_football\) "Jerry Williams
\(American football\)") as coach.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a0/1986_Jeno%27s_Pizza_-_05_-_Wilbert_Montgomery.jpg)](/wiki/File:1986_Jeno%27s_Pizza_-_05_-_Wilbert_Montgomery.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1986_Jeno%27s_Pizza_-_05_-_Wilbert_Montgomery.jpg "Enlarge")

The Eagles defeated the Cowboys in the [1980 NFC Championship
Game](/wiki/1980%E2%80%9381_NFL_playoffs#Conference_championships "1980–81 NFL
playoffs") and earned their first Super Bowl appearance.

With the [merger](/wiki/AFL%E2%80%93NFL_merger "AFL–NFL merger") of the NFL
and [AFL](/wiki/American_Football_League "American Football League") in 1970,
the Eagles were placed in the [NFC East](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC East") Division
with their [archrivals](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Giants_rivalry "Eagles–Giants
rivalry") the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants"), the
[Washington Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins"), and
the [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"). Their heated
[rivalry](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Giants_rivalry "Eagles–Giants rivalry") with
the Giants is the oldest of the [NFC East](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC East")
rivalries, dating all the way back to 1933 and is often named as one of the
best rivalries in the NFL.[16][17]

### 1976–1984

In [1976](/wiki/1976_NFL_season "1976 NFL season"), [Dick
Vermeil](/wiki/Dick_Vermeil "Dick Vermeil") was hired from
[UCLA](/wiki/UCLA_Bruins_football "UCLA Bruins football") to coach the Eagles,
who had only one winning season from 1962–1975.[18] Starting in
[1978](/wiki/1978_NFL_season "1978 NFL season"), head coach Dick Vermeil and
quarterback [Ron Jaworski](/wiki/Ron_Jaworski "Ron Jaworski") led the team to
four consecutive playoff appearances.

Vermeil's [1980 team](/wiki/1980_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "1980 Philadelphia
Eagles season") won their first [NFC East](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC East") title.
They were matched up against their hated rival the Dallas Cowboys in the NFC
Championship game, which they won 20–7. However, the Eagles lost to the
[Oakland Raiders](/wiki/1980_Oakland_Raiders_season "1980 Oakland Raiders
season") in [Super Bowl XV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XV "Super Bowl XV") in 1981. The
following year, the Eagles were eliminated in the wildcard round at home
against the New York Giants. In the aftermath of the disappointing and strike-
shortened season of 1982, head coach Dick Vermeil resigned, claiming that he
was "burned out". Vermeil was replaced by defensive coordinator Marion
Campbell.

In January 1983, Tose announced that his daughter, Susan Fletcher, the Eagles'
vice president and legal counsel, would eventually succeed him as primary
owner of the Eagles. Then in 1984, rumors were circulating that Leonard Tose
was thinking about moving the team to Phoenix, Arizona due to financial
reasons.

### 1985–1993

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. In [1985](/wiki/1985_NFL_season "1985 NFL season"), Tose was forced to sell
the Eagles to [Norman Braman](/wiki/Norman_Braman "Norman Braman") and Ed
Leibowitz, highly successful automobile dealers from Florida, for a reported
$65 million (equal to $147,899,134 today) to pay off his more than $25 million
(equal to $56,884,282 today) in gambling debts at [Atlantic
City](/wiki/Atlantic_City,_New_Jersey "Atlantic City, New Jersey") casinos.

Philadelphia football struggled through the [Marion
Campbell](/wiki/Marion_Campbell "Marion Campbell") years of the mid-1980s and
was marked by a malaise in fan participation. However, in the 1985
Supplemental draft, the Eagles acquired the rights to [Memphis
Showboats](/wiki/Memphis_Showboats "Memphis Showboats")' elite pass rusher
Reggie White. In [1986](/wiki/1986_NFL_season "1986 NFL season"), the arrival
of head coach [Buddy Ryan](/wiki/Buddy_Ryan "Buddy Ryan") and his fiery
attitude rejuvenated team performance and ignited the fan base, but the Eagles
failed to win a playoff game during Ryan's tenure. Possibly the worst of these
losses was the so-called Fog Bowl in 1988 against the [Chicago
Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears"), which happened to be Ryan's
former team that he helped lead to a Super Bowl XX victory as defensive
coordinator. Ryan was fired on January 7, 1991, after an upset home playoff
loss to the [Redskins](/wiki/1990_Washington_Redskins_season "1990 Washington
Redskins season"). Offensive coordinator [Rich Kotite](/wiki/Rich_Kotite "Rich
Kotite") was promoted to head coach three days later.

After All Pro defensive tackle [Jerome Brown](/wiki/Jerome_Brown "Jerome
Brown") was killed in an automobile accident, the team and fanbase became
dedicated to "bring it home for Jerome" in the [1992
season](/wiki/1992_NFL_season "1992 NFL season"). Kotite did lead the Eagles
to a playoff victory against the [New Orleans
Saints](/wiki/1992_New_Orleans_Saints_season "1992 New Orleans Saints season")
during the 1992 season, but they lost all-time sacks leader Reggie White to
free agency in the offseason. Kotie's contract was not renewed after a
disappointing [1994 season](/wiki/1994_NFL_season "1994 NFL season") in which
the Eagles went 7–9, losing their last seven games after starting the season
7–2. From 1988 to 1996, the Eagles qualified for the playoffs during six out
of those nine seasons, but they won the NFC East only once, in
[1988](/wiki/1988_NFL_season "1988 NFL season"). Among the team's offensive
stars during that period were quarterback [Randall
Cunningham](/wiki/Randall_Cunningham "Randall Cunningham"), tight end [Keith
Jackson](/wiki/Keith_Jackson_\(tight_end\) "Keith Jackson \(tight end\)"), and
running back [Herschel Walker](/wiki/Herschel_Walker "Herschel Walker"). But
the "Gang Green" defense is possibly what defined the team, led by [Reggie
White](/wiki/Reggie_White "Reggie White"), [Jerome Brown](/wiki/Jerome_Brown
"Jerome Brown"), [Clyde Simmons](/wiki/Clyde_Simmons "Clyde Simmons"), [Seth
Joyner](/wiki/Seth_Joyner "Seth Joyner"), [Wes Hopkins](/wiki/Wes_Hopkins "Wes
Hopkins"), [Mike Golic](/wiki/Mike_Golic "Mike Golic"), [Byron
Evans](/wiki/Byron_Evans "Byron Evans"), [Eric Allen](/wiki/Eric_Allen "Eric
Allen"), [Andre Waters](/wiki/Andre_Waters "Andre Waters") and [Mark
McMillian](/wiki/Mark_McMillian "Mark McMillian").

### Lurie era (1994–present)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(December 2010)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Jeff_Garcia_and_Andy_Reid.jpg/220px-
Jeff_Garcia_and_Andy_Reid.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jeff_Garcia_and_Andy_Reid.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jeff_Garcia_and_Andy_Reid.jpg "Enlarge")

Andy Reid speaks with Jeff Garcia in a game against the Redskins.

[Jeffrey Lurie](/wiki/Jeffrey_Lurie "Jeffrey Lurie") bought the Eagles on May
6, 1994 from then-owner Norman Braman for an estimated $185 million. The club
is now estimated to be the 17th most valuable sports team, worth $1.314
billion, as valuated in 2014 by Forbes.[19]

In Lurie's first season as owner, the team only had 7 wins, but that was
followed by a 10 win season in 1995. Besides the 10 wins and a playoff berth,
[1996](/wiki/1996_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "1996 Philadelphia Eagles
season") was an eventful year. The uniforms changed from the classic shade of
Kelly Green to a darker [midnight green](/wiki/Midnight_green "Midnight
green"), quarterback Randall Cunningham left after 11 seasons, and future fan
favorite 13-year starter [Brian Dawkins](/wiki/Brian_Dawkins "Brian Dawkins")
was drafted in the 2nd round. After slipping to 6–9–1, and then to 3–13, head
coach [Ray Rhodes](/wiki/Ray_Rhodes "Ray Rhodes") was fired after four
seasons.

#### Andy Reid era (1999–2012)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Jeffrey-
Lurie_August-2010.jpg/220px-Jeffrey-
Lurie_August-2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jeffrey-Lurie_August-2010.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jeffrey-Lurie_August-2010.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jeffrey Lurie](/wiki/Jeffrey_Lurie "Jeffrey Lurie") has been owner since
1994.

In [1999](/wiki/1999_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "1999 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), the Eagles hired head coach [Andy Reid](/wiki/Andy_Reid "Andy Reid")
and [drafted](/wiki/1999_NFL_draft "1999 NFL draft") quarterback [Donovan
McNabb](/wiki/Donovan_McNabb "Donovan McNabb"). From 1999 until 2004, the team
continually improved, going from 5–11 in 1999, returning to the playoffs in
with an 11–5 record in 2000, surpassing the Buccaneers in the Wild Card round
before losing in the divisional. Moreover, the Eagles played in four straight
NFC Championship Games between 2001 and 2004. In
[2001](/wiki/2001_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2001 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), the Eagles stayed at 11–5, beating the Buccaneers and Bears to
advance to the NFC championship, where they lost to the [St. Louis
Rams](/wiki/2001_St._Louis_Rams_season "2001 St. Louis Rams season"). In
[2002](/wiki/2002_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2002 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), the Eagles drafted running back [Brian
Westbrook](/wiki/Brian_Westbrook "Brian Westbrook"), got the 1st round bye
with the 2nd seed in the NFC with a 12–4 record, but the [Tampa Bay
Buccaneers](/wiki/2002_Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers_season "2002 Tampa Bay Buccaneers
season") got their revenge in the Championship and eliminated the Eagles. In
[2003](/wiki/2003_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2003 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), they won the NFC first seed, but Westbrook went down in Week 17,
culminating in a loss to the [Carolina
Panthers](/wiki/2003_Carolina_Panthers_season "2003 Carolina Panthers season")
in their 3rd straight NFC Championship.

##### 2004 Season and Super Bowl XXXIX

In [2004](/wiki/2004_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2004 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), the Philadelphia Eagles had their best season since 1960, going 13–1
before resting their starters and losing their next 2, clinching the 1st seed
for the second year in a row. McNabb set career highs, completing 64% of his
passes for 3,875 yards, though he didn't play all 16 games. McNabb became the
first quarterback ever to throw more than 30 touchdowns and fewer than 10
interceptions in a season. His success could be attributed to the fact that he
had a reliable receiver, [Terrell Owens](/wiki/Terrell_Owens "Terrell Owens"),
who got 1,200 yards and 14 touchdowns in 14 games. After beating the Vikings
and Falcons the Eagles advanced to [Super Bowl XXXIX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXIX
"Super Bowl XXXIX"), where they dueled the [New England
Patriots](/wiki/2004_New_England_Patriots_season "2004 New England Patriots
season"). Although McNabb threw 3 touchdown passes and 357 yards in the game,
and the score was tied 14–14 going into the fourth quarter, the Patriots
outscored the Eagles and scored ten straight points. McNabb completed a
30-yard touchdown pass, and the Eagles defense held the Patriots to a 3 and
out, but a crucial interception with 46 seconds left on the clock secured
their fate.

##### 2005-2012

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Brian_Dawkins.jpg/200px-
Brian_Dawkins.jpg)](/wiki/File:Brian_Dawkins.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Brian_Dawkins.jpg "Enlarge")

[Brian Dawkins](/wiki/Brian_Dawkins "Brian Dawkins") was one of the premier
safeties in the NFL, and earned him the role of Eagles' defensive captain, and
a mainstay on the Eagles.[20]

The team took a step back in [2005](/wiki/2005_Philadelphia_Eagles_season
"2005 Philadelphia Eagles season") with a 6–10 record. McNabb had played with
a sports hernia and a broken thumb, starting 4–2 but losing three in a row,
before McNabb finally succumbs to injury and is out for the rest of the
season. For obnoxious behavior and a feud with McNabb, Owens was suspended
after 7 games, eventually being cut. In
[2006](/wiki/2006_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2006 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), the team lost McNabb 10 games in and went into turmoil, but
Westbrook stepped up, and the Eagles earned their fifth NFC East title under
Coach Reid, with a 10–6 record and a win in the wild card round, but they had
an 8–8 2007 season. In [2008](/wiki/2008_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2008
Philadelphia Eagles season"), the team won their 500th game, and they also
drafted [DeSean Jackson](/wiki/DeSean_Jackson "DeSean Jackson"), a receiving
threat when paired with McNabb.[21]

On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion and
1st seed [New York Giants](/wiki/2008_New_York_Giants_season "2008 New York
Giants season") 23–11 en route to their 5th NFC Championship Game in 8 years
and 5th in the 10 years the Eagles have been coached by Andy Reid. In the 2008
NFC Championship Game, the Eagles made a rally, going from 24–6 at halftime to
25–24 with three minutes left in the 4th, but they lost to the [Arizona
Cardinals](/wiki/2008_Arizona_Cardinals_season "2008 Arizona Cardinals
season") by a score of 32–25 after quarterback [Kurt Warner](/wiki/Kurt_Warner
"Kurt Warner") scored a last minute touchdown. As of the conclusion of the
2016 season, during the Lurie era, the Eagles are 1–4 in conference
championship games and 0–1 in Super Bowls.

On August 13, 2009, the Eagles signed quarterback [Michael
Vick](/wiki/Michael_Vick "Michael Vick").[22] On December 6, 2009, [Andy
Reid](/wiki/Andy_Reid "Andy Reid") became only the 5th coach in NFL history to
win 100 or more games with a single team in a single decade. The other four
are [Tom Landry](/wiki/Tom_Landry "Tom Landry"), [Don Shula](/wiki/Don_Shula
"Don Shula"), [Tony Dungy](/wiki/Tony_Dungy "Tony Dungy"), and [Bill
Belichick](/wiki/Bill_Belichick "Bill Belichick"), all Super Bowl winners.[23]
McNabb finally had a complete receiving corps, between first round draft pick
[Jeremy Maclin](/wiki/Jeremy_Maclin "Jeremy Maclin"), DeSean Jackson's 1,000
yard season, and [Brent Celek](/wiki/Brent_Celek "Brent Celek") ranking among
the top 5 tight ends in the league. Without Brian Dawkins, defensive end
[Trent Cole](/wiki/Trent_Cole "Trent Cole") stepped up and became the dominant
force on defense with 12 sacks, earning him his second trip to the Pro Bowl
and All-Pro honors. In 2009, the Eagles started 5–4, but moved up to 11–4, and
could clinch the NFC 2nd seed if they won their next game. After a shutout at
the hands of the Dallas Cowboys in week 17, the Eagles missed the 1st round
bye. but with a record of 11–5, but they were the NFC 6th seed and they
narrowly made the playoffs. In the 2009 NFC Wild Card Game, the Eagles played
against the Cowboys for the second consecutive week and lost 34–14. Despite
many errors from many players, and a great season before the breakdown in
Dallas, McNabb took the brunt of the blow and was heavily criticized. Coach
Andy Reid said up until April 1, 2010, that McNabb would remain the starter.

On March 5, 2010, [Brian Westbrook](/wiki/Brian_Westbrook "Brian Westbrook")
was cut from the Eagles after eight seasons with the team. On April 4, 2010,
the team traded long-time starting quarterback [Donovan
McNabb](/wiki/Donovan_McNabb "Donovan McNabb") to the [Washington
Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins") in exchange for a
second round draft pick.[24] [Kevin Kolb](/wiki/Kevin_Kolb "Kevin Kolb") was
immediately named the starter, but after suffering a concussion in week 1
against the Packers, Vick took over as the starter. Vick led the Eagles to its
sixth NFC East division title in ten seasons. With a record of 10–6 the Eagles
clinched the 3rd seed and had to play a Wild Card Playoff Game. During the
2010 NFC Wild Card Game, the Eagles faced off against the eventual Super Bowl
champion [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/2010_Green_Bay_Packers_season "2010 Green
Bay Packers season") and lost 21–16.

The [2011 season](/wiki/2011_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2011 Philadelphia
Eagles season") for the Eagles was a major disappointment, as they only
managed to finish 8–8 and did not qualify for the playoffs, although they did
win the last 4 games of the season. Because of several free agent
acquisitions, [Vince Young](/wiki/Vince_Young "Vince Young"), a back up
quarterback, stated that the Eagles were a Dream Team. The Philadelphia fan
base and faithful never did concur with the comment as some national outlets
may comment. Many Eagles fans believe that Vince Young saying that the Eagles
were a 'Dream Team' is the reason that the Eagles had such a horrible season.

Eagles fans had high expectations going into the [2012
season](/wiki/2012_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2012 Philadelphia Eagles
season"). The Eagles started off winning three out of their four first games,
but that changed when they lost the next eight games, and were eliminated from
the playoff hunt. They only won one out of their last four games. After a loss
to the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") on December
30, 2012, longtime head coach [Andy Reid](/wiki/Andy_Reid "Andy Reid") was
fired after fourteen seasons with the team.[25]

#### Chip Kelly era (2013–2015)

On January 16, 2013, the Eagles brought in University of Oregon head coach
[Chip Kelly](/wiki/Chip_Kelly "Chip Kelly") to succeed Reid as head coach
after a 4–12 season.[26] The Philadelphia Eagles named Michael Vick starting
quarterback going into the 2013 season with much promise running Chip Kelly's
fast-paced spread offense.

The 2013 season proved to be more successful for the Eagles. A hamstring
injury took Michael Vick out after a 1–3 start, but his backup, Nick Foles,
led the team to a 10–6 regular season record, and its seventh NFC East title
in 13 seasons. Before throwing his first interception in Week 14, Foles threw
19 touchdowns, which was just one shy of the all-time NFL record of
consecutive touchdowns without an interception to start a season, set earlier
in the season by [Peyton Manning](/wiki/Peyton_Manning "Peyton Manning").
Foles also tied Manning for most touchdown passes in a single-game with seven
against the [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders") which
also made him the youngest player in NFL history to throw that many touchdowns
in a game. Foles finished the regular season with 27 touchdown passes and only
2 interceptions, giving him the then-best TD-INT ratio in NFL history. (That
record was later broken by [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady"), in the
2016 season.) He also finished with a 119.0 passer rating, third highest in
league history behind only [Aaron Rodgers](/wiki/Aaron_Rodgers "Aaron
Rodgers") in 2011 and Peyton Manning in 2004. He was also only the second
quarterback in NFL history to have a game in which he topped 400 passing yards
and a perfect passer rating. [LeSean McCoy](/wiki/LeSean_McCoy "LeSean McCoy")
finished his Pro Bowl season as the league's top rusher with 1,607 rushing
yards (also a franchise record) and 2,146 total yards from scrimmage, also
best in the NFL. As a whole, the Eagles offense scored 51 touchdowns, most in
franchise history passing the previous season high set back in 1948.

The Eagles opened the 2014 season winning their first three games and making
NFL history as the only team ever to trail by ten or more points in their
first three games and come back to win.[27] Nick Foles struggled with
turnovers, but ultimately did well and led the Eagles to a 6–2 record, before
breaking his collarbone, resulting in his job getting taken over by [Mark
Sanchez](/wiki/Mark_Sanchez "Mark Sanchez"), who outplayed Foles despite
facing more playoff teams. The Eagles held the divisional title from week one
to week 15 against the Cowboys. After going 9–3 with their crucial win over
the Cowboys, the Eagles lost their next 3, and a week after losing the NFC
East title, they lost an upset against the 3–11 Redskins and were eliminated
from playoff contention with the Cowboys' win over the Colts.

Following the 2014 season, Chip Kelly was given total control and made some
controversial moves. He traded [LeSean McCoy](/wiki/LeSean_McCoy "LeSean
McCoy"), who had become the team's all-time leading rusher after the 2014
season, for linebacker [Kiko Alonso](/wiki/Kiko_Alonso "Kiko Alonso"), a
player Kelly coached at Oregon who had missed the entire 2014 season.[28] He
also cut ten-year veteran and starter, Trent Cole, who was still a consistent
threat on defense and was second only to legend [Reggie
White](/wiki/Reggie_White "Reggie White") on the Eagles all-time sack
list.[29] He also made a trade where the highly successful [Nick
Foles](/wiki/Nick_Foles "Nick Foles") was traded for [Sam
Bradford](/wiki/Sam_Bradford "Sam Bradford"), who had missed the entire 2014
season with an ACL tear.[30] Kelly tried to re-sign Jeremy Maclin, who had
stepped up as the team's leading wide receiver, but he signed with the [Kansas
City Chiefs](/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs "Kansas City Chiefs") instead. However,
the Eagles also acquired league leading rusher [DeMarco
Murray](/wiki/DeMarco_Murray "DeMarco Murray"),[31] which not only helped the
Eagles, but hurt their rivals, the Dallas Cowboys. They also obtained Super
Bowl champion [Byron Maxwell](/wiki/Byron_Maxwell "Byron Maxwell"),[32] who
left the Seattle Seahawks in free agency to sign a six-year, $63 million
contract. The first two games of the season were disastrous, as they started
0–2. Bradford had a 2–4 TD-INT ratio, Maxwell was constantly beaten by Falcons
receiver [Julio Jones](/wiki/Julio_Jones "Julio Jones"), and Murray was held
to 11 yards on 21 carries. After Murray was injured, [Ryan
Mathews](/wiki/Ryan_Mathews_\(American_football\) "Ryan Mathews \(American
football\)") rushed for over 100 yards in a Week 3 win against the New York
Jets. Kelly made Murray the unquestioned starter and although Murray's play
improved over the season, he never regained his dominant form and was held to
a career low 3.6 yards per carry average.

On December 29, 2015, with one game left in the season, head coach Chip Kelly
was released by the Eagles. Offensive Coordinator Pat Shurmur was named
Interim Coach for the final game against the rival New York Giants, which
Shurmur won 35–30.[33] Former player and current running backs coach [Duce
Staley](/wiki/Duce_Staley "Duce Staley") was the first coach to be interviewed
for the opening head coaching job on January 2, 2016.[34]

#### Doug Pederson era (2016–present)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Carson_wentz_2016.jpg/220px-
Carson_wentz_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:Carson_wentz_2016.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Carson_wentz_2016.jpg "Enlarge")

[Carson Wentz](/wiki/Carson_Wentz "Carson Wentz") made his debut in the [2016
season](/wiki/2016_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2016 Philadelphia Eagles
season")

The Eagles hired [Chiefs](/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs "Kansas City Chiefs")
[offensive coordinator](/wiki/Offensive_coordinator "Offensive coordinator")
[Doug Pederson](/wiki/Doug_Pederson "Doug Pederson") as their next head coach.
The team made the official announcement on January 18, 2016. Eagles owner
[Jeffrey Lurie](/wiki/Jeffrey_Lurie "Jeffrey Lurie") said in a statement:

> "Doug is a strategic thinker, a compelling leader and communicator, and
> someone who truly knows how to get the best out of his players. All of these
> factors were what initially attracted us to Doug and we believe that he is
> the right man to help us achieve our ultimate goal."

Pederson had been with the Chiefs for the preceding three years after spending
the four seasons previous to those with the Eagles. He served as a quality
control assistant for the Eagles in 2009 and 2010 before being promoted to
quarterbacks coach for the 2011 and 2012 seasons. He was praised for his work
with Chiefs quarterback Alex Smith over the preceding few seasons,
particularly 2015, as the Chiefs moved into the top 10 in scoring
offense.[35][36]

At the end of the 2015 season, the Eagles had the 13th pick in the [2016 NFL
Draft](/wiki/2016_NFL_Draft "2016 NFL Draft"). They traded [Byron
Maxwell](/wiki/Byron_Maxwell "Byron Maxwell"), [Kiko Alonso](/wiki/Kiko_Alonso
"Kiko Alonso"), and their pick to the [Miami Dolphins](/wiki/Miami_Dolphins
"Miami Dolphins") for the #8 pick. Later, they traded the #8 pick, their
third-round pick, their fourth-round pick, a 2017 first-round pick, and a 2018
second-round pick to the [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland
Browns") for the #2 pick and a 2017 fourth-round pick. They used the #2 pick
to draft [North Dakota State](/wiki/North_Dakota_State_Bison_football "North
Dakota State Bison football") quarterback [Carson Wentz](/wiki/Carson_Wentz
"Carson Wentz"). On September 3, 2016, the Eagles traded starting quarterback
[Sam Bradford](/wiki/Sam_Bradford "Sam Bradford") to the [Minnesota
Vikings](/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings"), who had lost [Teddy
Bridgewater](/wiki/Teddy_Bridgewater "Teddy Bridgewater") for the season, for
a 2017 first-round pick and a 2018 fourth-round pick. Following the trade, the
Eagles named Wentz the starting quarterback for Week 1 of the 2016 season.[37]
First-time head coach Pederson led the Eagles to a 3–0 start to the season.
His rookie quarterback started with 5 touchdowns, no interceptions and over
255 yards per game. The Week 4 bye took a toll on the Eagles, and they lost
four out of the next five games, including a loss to every rival team in their
division. They also lost right tackle [Lane Johnson](/wiki/Lane_Johnson "Lane
Johnson") to a 10-game suspension following the Week 5 loss againist the Lions
which damaged Carson Wentz's hot start. In those four games, their average
margin of loss was just under 5 points.[38] Pederson and the Eagles won just 3
of their last 7 games. Those included gruesome road losses against the
[Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle Seahawks"), the [Cincinnati
Bengals](/wiki/Cincinnati_Bengals "Cincinnati Bengals"), and the [Baltimore
Ravens](/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens"). Although Wentz started off
the season well, the 6–5 quarterback finished with a TD–INT ratio of 16:14.
The rookie head coach and rookie quarterback tandem led the Eagles to a
disappointing year, finishing with a 7–9 record and coming in last in the
division.

##### 2017: First Super Bowl championship

During the following offseason, the team made several acquisitions on the
offensive side of the ball. The Eagles either traded or released notable
players from the [Chip Kelly](/wiki/Chip_Kelly "Chip Kelly") era like [Ryan
Mathews](/wiki/Ryan_Mathews_\(American_football\) "Ryan Mathews \(American
football\)"), [Matt Tobin](/wiki/Matt_Tobin "Matt Tobin"), [Allen
Barbre](/wiki/Allen_Barbre "Allen Barbre"), [Jordan
Matthews](/wiki/Jordan_Matthews "Jordan Matthews") and [Marcus Smith
II](/wiki/Marcus_Smith_II "Marcus Smith II"). They signed more notable players
to improve its wide receiver corps that have struggled the last two seasons
like [Alshon Jeffery](/wiki/Alshon_Jeffery "Alshon Jeffery"), and [Torrey
Smith](/wiki/Torrey_Smith "Torrey Smith") as well as 2016 Super Bowl champion,
[Legarrette Blount](/wiki/Legarrette_Blount "Legarrette Blount"). They also
added veterans on defense such as [Patrick
Robinson](/wiki/Patrick_Robinson_\(cornerback\) "Patrick Robinson
\(cornerback\)"), [Chris Long](/wiki/Chris_Long "Chris Long"), [Corey
Graham](/wiki/Corey_Graham "Corey Graham"), [Tim Jernigan](/wiki/Tim_Jernigan
"Tim Jernigan") and [Ronald Darby](/wiki/Ronald_Darby "Ronald Darby"). The
team addressed its defense mostly in the draft, using its top three picks on
defensive players. The Eagles drafted [Derek Barnett](/wiki/Derek_Barnett
"Derek Barnett") with the 14th overall pick. The Eagles had completely
revamped their offense and strengthened their defense heading into the 2017
season. They opened the season on the road versus the [Washington
Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins") and won the game
30–17. The team lost to the [Kansas City Chiefs](/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs
"Kansas City Chiefs") the following week, 27–20, in Pederson's return to face
[Andy Reid](/wiki/Andy_Reid "Andy Reid"). The Eagles then won six consecutive
games, including signature wins at the [Carolina
Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers"), 28–23, and versus the
[Washington Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins"), 34–24,
in a Monday Night contest. On the morning of October 31, 2017, just before the
NFL trade deadline, the Eagles made a blockbuster move sending a fourth-round
pick to the [Miami Dolphins](/wiki/Miami_Dolphins "Miami Dolphins") for star
running back [Jay Ajayi](/wiki/Jay_Ajayi "Jay Ajayi"). The move immediately
paid dividends for the Eagles heading into their next game versus the [Denver
Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos") as Ajayi rushed for 77 yards
on just eight attempts including a 46-yard TD near the end of the second
quarter. Ajayi and Wentz led the Eagles to a 51–23 rout of the top defense in
the NFL.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Nick_Foles_Super_bowl_LII_pregame_huddle.jpg/206px-
Nick_Foles_Super_bowl_LII_pregame_huddle.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nick_Foles_Super_bowl_LII_pregame_huddle.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Nick_Foles_Super_bowl_LII_pregame_huddle.jpg "Enlarge")

Foles in the Huddle before leaving the field before [Super Bowl
LII](//commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_LII&action=edit&redlink=1).

The Eagles headed into their bye week with the best record in the NFL (8–1),
and with Wentz leading the NFL MVP discussion with an NFL-leading 23
touchdowns to 5 interceptions. During their bye, the Eagles signed former
Giants offensive tackle [Will Beatty](/wiki/Will_Beatty "Will Beatty") and
former Saints linebacker [Dannell Ellerbe](/wiki/Dannell_Ellerbe "Dannell
Ellerbe") to not only add depth but also players with Super Bowl experiences.
Coming off of the bye week, the Philadelphia Eagles entered a Sunday night
showdown with the defending NFC East champion [Dallas
Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"). The Eagles came out sluggish
and trailed 9–7 at the half. The team exploded in the second half though,
rattling off 30 unanswered points to soundly defeat their rival by a final
score of 37–9. The Eagles were rolling on a nine-game winning streak after a
huge blowout win over the [Chicago Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago
Bears").[28] The Eagles traveled to Seattle in Week 13 in a huge Sunday Night
showdown against [Russell Wilson](/wiki/Russell_Wilson "Russell Wilson") and
the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle Seahawks"). The Eagles
struggled throughout the whole game, blowing many scoring opportunities and
allowing Wilson to throw 3 touchdowns. The Eagles lost 24–10, ending their win
streak. However, the Eagles bounced back in Week 14 win over the [Los Angeles
Rams](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Rams "Los Angeles Rams") in a tough 43–35 win.
However, Carson Wentz left the game in the third quarter with a knee injury.
It was later found out that Wentz tore his ACL, ending his MVP caliber season.
Backup [Nick Foles](/wiki/Nick_Foles "Nick Foles") would once again take over
as starting quarterback. In Foles's first start against the New York Giants,
he would lead them back from a 20–7 deficit and score 4 touchdowns and win the
game 34–29. Foles struggled in the last two games of the season against the
[Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders") and the [Dallas
Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"), and threw a touchdown and 2
interceptions in that span. Despite this, the Eagles finished 13–3 and secured
the top seed in the NFC. The Eagles opened as the underdogs, the first time in
history that a No. 1 seed has opened up the postseason as an underdog. Despite
this, Foles would lead the Eagles past the [Atlanta
Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons "Atlanta Falcons") in the Divisional Round
15–10. In the next game Foles and the Eagles annihilated the [Minnesota
Vikings](/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings") 38–7 in the NFC
Championship nicknamed the Minneapolis Massacre, mocking the Minneapolis
Miracle from their previous playoff victory. Foles had his best game since
week 15 and threw for 352 passing yards and 3 touchdowns including an
impressive flea flicker touchdown pass. This win marked the franchise's third
Super Bowl appearance and a berth in [Super Bowl LII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII
"Super Bowl LII") for a 2005 rematch against [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom
Brady") and the [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England
Patriots").

With Foles at the helm, the Eagles started off the game strong, leading the
Patriots 22–12 at halftime. In the second half the Patriots gained momentum
and for the first time took the lead in the 4th quarter 33–32. The Eagles
rallied back and scored an 11-yard Touchdown to tight end [Zach
Ertz](/wiki/Zach_Ertz "Zach Ertz"). Later the Eagles converted on a 46-yard
field goal by [Jake Elliott](/wiki/Jake_Elliott "Jake Elliott") to lead 41–33.
On the final play of the game with 9 seconds left, Brady threw a hail-mary
pass directed toward tight end [Rob Gronkowski](/wiki/Rob_Gronkowski "Rob
Gronkowski") which was bobbled by Patrick Robinson before being dropped in the
end-zone as time expired, securing the win for the Eagles 41–33, and ending
the 58-year long championship drought. This would be Philadelphia's first
Super Bowl win and their fourth league championship (their first championship
since [1960](/wiki/1960 "1960")). Foles won Super Bowl MVP going 28–43 with
373 passing yards, 3 touchdowns, and an interception. [Nick
Foles](/wiki/Nick_Foles "Nick Foles") became the first backup quarterback to
start and win a Super Bowl since his opponent [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom
Brady") won as the backup for [Drew Bledsoe](/wiki/Drew_Bledsoe "Drew
Bledsoe") in [2001](/wiki/2001 "2001").

seasons](/wiki/List_of_Philadelphia_Eagles_seasons "List of Philadelphia
Eagles seasons")

  * Regular season record (all-time): 568–594–26
  * Playoff record (all-time): 22–21 (last appearance after beating New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII)
  * Most points in a season: 474 points (2014)
  * NFL championships won: 4 (3 before the 1967 NFL-AFL merger created the Super Bowl)
  * Super Bowls won: 1 out of 3 appearances

  * Rushing leader (all-time): LeSean McCoy – 6,792 yards
  * Receiving leader (all-time): Harold Carmichael – 8,978 yards
  * Winningest coach (all-time): Andy Reid – 130 wins
  * Top player by approximate value (all-time): Donovan McNabb – 126 AV

## Rivalries

### New York Giants

Main article: [Eagles–Giants rivalry](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Giants_rivalry
"Eagles–Giants rivalry")

One of the NFL's oldest, this rivalry began on October 15, 1933[39] when the
Giants defeated the newly founded Eagles 56–0. The Giants lead the all-time
series 84–82–2. Three of the best known comebacks against the Giants are
labeled as "Miracle In The Meadowlands – Herm Edwards", "Miracle In The
Meadowlands II – Brian Westbrook" and "Miracle In The New Meadowlands – DeSean
Jackson".

### Dallas Cowboys

Main article: [Cowboys–Eagles rivalry](/wiki/Cowboys%E2%80%93Eagles_rivalry
"Cowboys–Eagles rivalry")

The Cowboys have been one of the Eagles' biggest rivals. The Eagles won the
first game in this rivalry 27–25 on September 30, 1960. Dallas leads the all-
time series 63–51–0. They have been close in recent years, with Dallas winning
12 games from 2006 to the present while the Eagles have also won 12. There is
much hostility between the two teams' fan bases, with incidents such as the
1989 [Bounty Bowl](/wiki/Bounty_Bowl "Bounty Bowl").

### Washington Redskins

Main article: [Eagles–Redskins rivalry](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Redskins_rivalry
"Eagles–Redskins rivalry")

Not as big as the rivalries between the Giants and Cowboys, that with division
rivals Washington Redskins is still fierce. It started in 1934 when the
Washington Redskins were first known as the Boston Redskin; the Redskins
defeated the Eagles 6–0, and lead the all-time series 85–76–6. The rivalry has
been very even since 2010 overall. However, the Eagles swept the Redskins
during the 2017 season for the first time since the 2013 season.

### Pittsburgh Steelers

Main article: [Eagles–Steelers rivalry](/wiki/Eagles%E2%80%93Steelers_rivalry
"Eagles–Steelers rivalry")

The Eagles and [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh
Steelers") are both located in [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania
"Pennsylvania") and began play in 1933. From that season, through 1966, this
was a major rivalry for both teams as both were part of the same division. In
1967, they were placed in separate divisions but remained in the same
conference for three years. Finally, in 1970, the Steelers (along with the
[Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") and [Baltimore
Colts](/wiki/Baltimore_Colts "Baltimore Colts")) moved to the [American
Football Conference](/wiki/American_Football_Conference "American Football
Conference") while the Eagles stayed with the rest of the old-line NFL teams
in the [National Football Conference](/wiki/National_Football_Conference
"National Football Conference"). As a result, the Eagles and Steelers no
longer played each other every year. Currently they are scheduled to meet once
every four years in the regular season, the most recent meeting being in 2016
at Philadelphia, with the Eagles winning 34-3. The Steelers have lost nine
straight games on the road against the Eagles dating back to 1966, which was
also the start of the [Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") era. The
Eagles lead the all-time series 47–28–3.

## Logo and uniforms

    _See also:[Uniform (American football)](/wiki/Uniform_\(American_football\) "Uniform \(American football\)") and footnote about Eagles' uniform numbers._[40]

For several decades, the Eagles' [colors](/wiki/Away_colours "Away colours")
were [kelly green](/wiki/Kelly_green "Kelly green"), silver, and white. In
1954, the Eagles, along with the [Baltimore Colts](/wiki/Baltimore_Colts
"Baltimore Colts"), became the second team ever in the NFL to put a
[logo](/wiki/Logo#Sports "Logo") on their [helmets](/wiki/Football_helmet
"Football helmet"), with silver wings on a kelly green helmet. In 1969, the
team wore two helmet versions: Kelly green with white wings in road games, and
white with kelly green wings at home. From 1970 to '73, they wore the white
helmets with Kelly green wings exclusively before switching back to Kelly
green helmets with silver wings. By 1974, Joseph A. Scirrotto Jr. designed the
silver wings took on a white outline, and this style on a kelly green helmet
became standard for over two decades.

From 1948–95, the team logo was an eagle in flight carrying a football in its
claws, although from '69–72, the eagle took on a more stylized look. As the
design was similar to the _[Apollo 11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11")_ emblem,
and its [moon-landing craft](/wiki/Apollo_Lunar_Module "Apollo Lunar Module")
was dubbed _Eagle_ , players wore the flight's mission patch on their jerseys
during 1969.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 1973, the team's name was added below the eagle, which returned to its
pre-'69 look.

However, both the logo and uniforms were radically altered in 1996. The
primary kelly green color was changed to a darker shade, officially described
as "midnight green." Silver was practically abandoned, as uniform pants moved
to either white or midnight green. The traditional helmet wings were changed
to a primarily white color, with silver and black accents. The team's logo
combination (the eagle and club name lettering) also changed in 1996, with the
eagle itself limited to a white (bald eagle) head, drawn in a less realistic,
more cartoon-based style, and the lettering changing from calligraphic to
block letters.

Since the 1996 alterations, the team has made only minor alterations, mostly
relating to jersey/pant combinations worn during specific games. For example,
in 1997, against the [San Francisco
49ers](/wiki/1997_San_Francisco_49ers_season "1997 San Francisco 49ers
season"), the team wore midnight green jerseys and pants for the first of only
two occasions in team history. The second occasion was in 2002, during the
final regular season game at [Veterans Stadium](/wiki/Veterans_Stadium
"Veterans Stadium"), a win over the division-rival [Washington
Redskins](/wiki/2002_Washington_Redskins_season "2002 Washington Redskins
season"). A year later, in the first two games of the 2003 season (both home
losses to the [Tampa Bay Buccaneers](/wiki/2003_Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers_season
"2003 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season") and [New England
Patriots](/wiki/2003_New_England_Patriots_season "2003 New England Patriots
season")), the Eagles wore white jerseys with white pants. Since 2003, the
white jerseys along with white pants have been worn during preseason games.

The 2003 season also saw the first (though only subtle) change to the
1996-style uniform. On both white and green jerseys, black shadows and silver
trim were added to both the green and white numbering. The stripe on the pants
changed from black-green-black to black-silver-green on the white pants, and
from a solid black stripe to one stripe of black, another of silver, with one
small white stripe in between for the midnight blue pants. The 2003 season
also saw the team debut black alternate jerseys, with a green (instead of
black) shadow on white numbers, and silver trim. These black jerseys have been
worn for two selected [home](/wiki/Home_\(sports\) "Home \(sports\)") games
each season (usually the first home game after [bye](/wiki/Bye_\(sports\) "Bye
\(sports\)") week and the season finale). In the 2003 and 2004 regular season
home finales, the team wore the green [road](/wiki/Road_\(sports\) "Road
\(sports\)") pants with the black alternate jerseys, but lost each game. Since
then, the Eagles have only worn the black jerseys with the white pants.
However, due to the special 75th anniversary uniforms serving as the
"alternates" for one game in 2007, the Eagles could not wear the alternate
black jersey that season per league rules (alternate uniforms are permitted
twice per season but only one can be used). The black jerseys with white
pants, however, re-appeared for the 2008
[Thanksgiving](/wiki/NFL_on_Thanksgiving_Day "NFL on Thanksgiving Day") night
game against the [Arizona Cardinals](/wiki/2008_Arizona_Cardinals_season "2008
Arizona Cardinals season"). The black jerseys were most recently used in a
December 21, 2016 game against the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants
"New York Giants"), in which they won 24-19. From 2006–2013, the Eagles have
only worn the alternate black jerseys once a season and for the last November
home game, but did not use them in 2007, 2010, and 2011. For the 2007 and 2010
seasons, the Eagles used throwback uniforms in place of the black alternates
for their anniversary to commemorate past teams. The team also started wearing
black shoes exclusively in 2004. Since 2014, the Eagles have worn the black
jersey twice per season. In 2016, they wore the black jersey three times.

To celebrate the team's 75th anniversary, the 2007 uniforms featured a 75th-
season logo patch on the left shoulder. In addition, the team wore
["throwback" jerseys](/wiki/Throwback_uniform "Throwback uniform") in a 2007
game against the [Detroit Lions](/wiki/2007_Detroit_Lions_season "2007 Detroit
Lions season"). The yellow and blue jerseys, the same colors found on
[Philadelphia's city flag](/wiki/Flag_of_Philadelphia "Flag of Philadelphia"),
are based on those worn by the Philadelphia Eagles in the team's inaugural
season, and were the same colors used by the former [Frankford Yellow
Jackets](/wiki/Frankford_Yellow_Jackets "Frankford Yellow Jackets") franchise
prior to their suspension of operations in 1931. The Eagles beat Detroit,
56–21.[41]

The Philadelphia Eagles wear their white jerseys at home for preseason games
and daytime games in the first half of the regular season from September to
mid-October when the temperature is warmer. In night contests in the first
half of the regular season, the Eagles do not need to wear white at home since
the temperature is cooler. However, there have been exceptions, such as the
home opener against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in 2003 and the Washington
Redskins in 2007 that were played at night. In late October or beginning in
November, the Eagles start to wear their colors at home (although they have
done it earlier before), be it the midnight green jerseys or a third jersey.
On one occasion the Eagles wore white at home after October in a meeting
against the [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") on
November 4, 2007 to make the Cowboys wear their road blue jerseys. Since
moving to [Lincoln Financial Field](/wiki/Lincoln_Financial_Field "Lincoln
Financial Field") in 2003, the Eagles have worn white at home for at least
their home opener, with the exceptions for the 2010 home opener (_see next
paragraph_), the 2011 home opener against the [New York
Giants](/wiki/2011_New_York_Giants_season "2011 New York Giants season"), the
2016 home opener against the [Cleveland
Browns](/wiki/2016_Cleveland_Browns_season "2016 Cleveland Browns season"),
and the 2017 home opener against the Giants.

In the 2010 season against the Green Bay Packers, on September 12, 2010, the
Eagles wore uniforms similar to the ones that were worn by the 1960
championship team in honor the 50th anniversary of that team.[42] In weeks 4
and 6 of the 2010 season, the Eagles wore their white jerseys in a match-up
against the Washington Redskins and Atlanta Falcons respectively before
reverting to their midnight green jerseys for the rest of their home games.
For the 2011 season, the Eagles did not wear white for any of their home
games.

For the 2012 season [Nike](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc.") took over from
[Reebok](/wiki/Reebok "Reebok") as the NFL's official apparel licensee but the
Eagles decided that they would not be adopting Nike's "Elite 51" uniform
technology. Aside from the Nike logo replacing the Reebok logo, the only other
change is the league-wide revision of the NFL shield on the uniform (replacing
the NFL Equipment logo), other than that the uniforms essentially remain
unchanged. The Eagles also revived their black alternate jersey.

For the 2013 season, the Eagles started to wear white pants, as an alternate
to their green pants, with their white jerseys, in the regular season.

For the 2014 season the Eagles have officially adopted the "Elite 51″ style
uniform from Nike. Recently the team has discussed bringing back the "Kelly
Green" uniforms similar to the uniforms worn in the 1960 NFL Championship
season and which were last worn in the 2010 season opener vs. Green Bay.
Traditionally kelly green, silver and white had been the official team color
until 1996 season when it switched to the current "Midnight Green" uniforms.
But due to the NFL rules and restrictions having a team go through a waiting
period before any major uniform changes and alterations can be made, it would
most likely be quite some time before any uniform changes are officially made.

In Week 6 of 2014 against the New York Giants, the team introduced black pants
to complement their black jerseys, giving them a blackout uniform set, the
Eagles won the game 27–0. The victory was their first shutout in 18 years. The
blackout uniform was most recently worn in a Week 16 victory, 19-10, against
the Raiders in 2017. The Eagles are 6–3 in their blackout uniforms: winning
three times against the Giants and once against each of the [Minnesota
Vikings](/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings"), [Denver
Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos"), and Oakland Raiders, and
losing against the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle
Seahawks"), [Arizona Cardinals](/wiki/Arizona_Cardinals "Arizona Cardinals"),
and [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers").

## Training camp

The Eagles previously held their preseason training camp from the end of July
through mid-August each year at [Lehigh University](/wiki/Lehigh_University
"Lehigh University") in [Bethlehem,
Pennsylvania](/wiki/Bethlehem,_Pennsylvania "Bethlehem, Pennsylvania") in the
[Lehigh Valley](/wiki/Lehigh_Valley "Lehigh Valley").[43] With the addition of
new head coach [Chip Kelly](/wiki/Chip_Kelly "Chip Kelly"), the Eagles
recently moved their training camp to the [NovaCare
Complex](/wiki/NovaCare_Complex "NovaCare Complex") in
[Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia").[44][45] Training camps were
previously held at [Chestnut Hill Academy](/wiki/Chestnut_Hill_Academy
"Chestnut Hill Academy") in 1935, [Saint Joseph's
University](/wiki/Saint_Joseph%27s_University "Saint Joseph's University") in
1939 and 1943, [Saranac Lake](/wiki/Saranac_Lake,_New_York "Saranac Lake, New
York") from 1946–1948, [Hershey](/wiki/Hershey,_Pennsylvania "Hershey,
Pennsylvania") from 1951–1967, [Albright College](/wiki/Albright_College
"Albright College") from 1968–1972, [Widener
University](/wiki/Widener_University "Widener University") from 1973–1979, and
[West Chester University](/wiki/West_Chester_University_of_Pennsylvania "West
Chester University of Pennsylvania") from 1980–1995.[45]

### Devotion

Although the method may vary, studies that attempt to rank the 32 fan bases in
the NFL consistently place Eagles [fans](/wiki/Sports_fan "Sports fan") among
the best in the league, noting their "unmatched fervor."[46] Eagles fans have
numerous dedicated web communities, ranking the Eagles just behind the
Phillies as the dominant Philadelphia sports presence on the web.[47]

The [American City Business Journals](/wiki/American_City_Business_Journals
"American City Business Journals"), which conducts a regular study to
determine the most loyal fans in the NFL, evaluates fans based primarily on
attendance-related factors,[48] and ranked Eagles fans third in both 1999[49]
and 2006.[50] The 2006 study called the fans "incredibly loyal", noting that
they filled 99.8% of the seats in the stadium over the previous decade.[51]
_[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ placed the Eagles fans first in its 2008
survey,[52] which was based on the correlation between team performance and
fan attendance.[53] [ESPN.com](/wiki/ESPN.com "ESPN.com") placed Eagles fans
fourth in the league in its 2008 survey, citing the connection between the
team's performance and the mood of the city.[54] The last home game which was
blacked out on television in the Philadelphia market as a result of not being
sold out was against the Arizona Cardinals on Sunday, September 12, 1999,
which was Andy Reid's first home game as new head coach of the
Eagles.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

The studies note that—win or lose—Eagles fans can be counted on to pack their
stadium. As of August 2008, the team had sold out 71 consecutive games, and
70,000 were on the team's waiting list for season tickets.[54] Despite
finishing with a 6–10 record in the 2005 season, the Eagles ranked second in
the NFL in merchandise sales, and single-game tickets for the next season were
sold out minutes after phone and Internet lines opened.[55]

Eagles fans have also been known to chant the famous, "E-A-G-L-E-S – Eagles!!"
at [Flyers](/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers"),
[Phillies](/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies"), and
[76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers") games when the team is
getting [blown out](/wiki/Blowout_\(sports\) "Blowout \(sports\)") late in a
game and a loss is inevitable, signifying their displeasure with the given
team's performance, and that they are instead putting their hope into the
Eagles.

### Bad behavior

Along with their [fierce devotion](/wiki/Ultras "Ultras"), Eagles fans have [a
reputation for bad behavior](/wiki/Hooliganism "Hooliganism") and [sports-
related violence](/wiki/Violence_in_sports "Violence in sports"), especially
when the team plays its rivals.[56] In _If Football 's a Religion, Why Don't
We Have a Prayer?_, Jereé Longman described the fans of the [700
Level](/wiki/700_Level "700 Level") of Veterans Stadium as having a reputation
for "[hostile taunting](/wiki/Crowd_abuse "Crowd abuse"), fighting, public
urination and general strangeness."[57] So many incidents occurred at a 1997
game against the 49ers that at the following home game, Judge [Seamus
McCaffery](/wiki/Seamus_McCaffery "Seamus McCaffery") began presiding over a
temporary courtroom at the stadium; 20 suspects came before him that day.[56]
Fan behavior improved after the team's move to Lincoln Financial Field, and
"Eagles Court" ended in December 2003.[58]

### Eagles Hall of Fame

See also: [Category:American football museums and halls of
fame](/wiki/Category:American_football_museums_and_halls_of_fame
"Category:American football museums and halls of fame").

In 1987, the Eagles Honor Roll was established. Every Eagles player who had by
then been elected into the [Pro Football Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame") was among
the inaugural induction class. By 2012, the Honor Roll had been retitled as
the Eagles Hall of Fame.[63] Players are considered for induction three years
after their retirement from the NFL, and there have been 41 inductees into the
Eagles Hall of Fame as of 2015.[64]

From 2008 through 2010, Eagles games were broadcast on both rock-formatted
WYSP and sports-talk [Sports Radio 610 WIP](/wiki/WTEL_\(AM\) "WTEL \(AM\)"),
as both stations are owned and operated by [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") Radio. In
2011, CBS dropped the music on WYSP, renaming it [WIP-FM](/wiki/WIP-FM "WIP-
FM") and making it a full simulcast of WIP. Later, 610 AM became a CBS Sports
Radio national broadcast, and 94 WIP was broadcast on WIP FM. The Eagles
extended their broadcasting contract with WIP-FM through 2024.[66]

[Merrill Reese](/wiki/Merrill_Reese "Merrill Reese"), who joined the Eagles in
1976, is the play-by-play announcer, and former Eagles wide receiver [Mike
Quick](/wiki/Mike_Quick "Mike Quick"), who replaced the offense lineman Stan
Walters beginning in 1998, is the color analyst. The post game show, which has
consisted of many Philadelphia sports personalities, as of the 2014 season is
hosted by Kevin Riley, a former Eagles linebacker and special-teamer, and Rob
Ellis. Riley was the former post-game host for the show on 94 WYSP before the
WIP change over; Rob Ellis hosts a weekly show nightly from 6–10 on 94.1 WIP-
FM. No announcement was made prior to the start of preseason regarding who
would be the host(s) for 2015.

In 2015, the preseason games are being televised on [WCAU](/wiki/WCAU "WCAU"),
the local [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") [owned and operated
station](/wiki/Owned_and_operated_station "Owned and operated station").
Television announcers for these preseason games were not announced prior to
the start of preseason. During the regular season, games are governed by the
[NFL's master broadcasting
contract](/wiki/National_Football_League_on_television "National Football
League on television") with [FOX](/wiki/FOX "FOX"), [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS"),
[NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC"), and [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN"). Most games can be seen
on FOX-owned [WTXF-TV](/wiki/WTXF-TV "WTXF-TV"). When hosting an AFC team,
those games can be seen on CBS-owned [KYW-TV](/wiki/KYW-TV "KYW-TV").

## Media and cultural reference

In the book _[MASH: A Novel About Three Army
Doctors](/wiki/MASH:_A_Novel_About_Three_Army_Doctors "MASH: A Novel About
Three Army Doctors")_ , the character [Captain Oliver Wendell "Spearchucker"
Jones](/wiki/Spearchucker_Jones "Spearchucker Jones") fictionally played for
the Philadelphia Eagles, though in the movie this was changed to San
Francisco.

The [1976](/wiki/1976_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "1976 Philadelphia Eagles
season") draw was the subject of the movie
_[Invincible](/wiki/Invincible_\(2006_film\) "Invincible \(2006 film\)")_. The
movie stars [Mark Wahlberg](/wiki/Mark_Wahlberg "Mark Wahlberg") as [Vince
Papale](/wiki/Vince_Papale "Vince Papale"), a 30-year-old bartender and part-
time school teacher, and also a diehard Eagles fan who became an Eagles
player. The film differs slightly from true events as the selection process
was invitation only, and Papale had at least some previous playing
experience.[67] The film _[Silver Linings
Playbook](/wiki/Silver_Linings_Playbook "Silver Linings Playbook")_ highlights
the [2008 Philadelphia Eagles season](/wiki/2008_Philadelphia_Eagles_season
"2008 Philadelphia Eagles season"). The film was critically acclaimed and
nominated for several awards including 8 [Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards
"Academy Awards").

In the 1978 Academy Award-winning movie _[The Deer
Hunter](/wiki/The_Deer_Hunter "The Deer Hunter")_ , the Eagles are referenced
when Nick talks to Stan in the bar, saying: "Hey, I got a hundred bucks says
the Eagles never cross the fifty in the next half and Oakland wins by 20!"
Stan responds; "And I got an extra twenty says the Eagles' quarterback wears a
dress!"[68]

The award-winning comedy series _[It's Always Sunny in
Philadelphia](/wiki/It%27s_Always_Sunny_in_Philadelphia "It's Always Sunny in
Philadelphia")_ starring [Danny DeVito](/wiki/Danny_DeVito "Danny DeVito")
makes several references to the Philadelphia Eagles, most notably Season 3,
Episode 2 – "The Gang Gets Invincible," the title being a reference to the
Wahlberg film.[69]
